1 cavalry company |casualties1 =None |casualties2 =None |notes = |campaignbox = }} {{Campaignbox Lower Seaboard Theater and Gulf Approach}} The '''Battle of St. John's Bluff''' was fought from October 1–3, 1862, between [[Union Army|Union]] and [[Confederate States Army|Confederate]] forces in [[Duval County, Florida]], during the [[American Civil War]]. The battle resulted in a significant Union victory, helping secure their control of the [[Jacksonville]] area.{{cite web|title=St. John's Bluff|url=http://ehistory.osu.edu/battles/st-johns-bluff|website=ehistory.osu.edu|accessdate=14 May 2016}} ==History== The St. Johns River was important in the Union effort of taking Florida. If Federals controlled the St. Johns River then they could raid Confederate positions in the interior of Florida and also use the river as a barrier for control of the east. The Union wanted to control North Florida and use it as a haven for escaped slaves and use its position to initiate Reconstruction for Florida. Federals first occupied Jacksonville in March 1862. Federal gunboats stationed at Mayport Mills operated up and down the river. Early in the war, in order to stop the movement of [[Union Navy]] ships up the [[St. Johns River]], Confederate [[Brigadier General]] [[Joseph Finnegan (Brigadier general)|Joseph Finnegan]] established an [[artillery battery]] on St. Johns Bluff, on the south side of the river 18 miles downstream from [[Jacksonville, Florida]]. The Union victories at [[Battle of Fort Donelson|Fort Donelson]] and [[Battle of Fort Henry|Fort Henry]] forced Florida Confederates to go to Tennessee to reinforce the Confederate Army. With few resources Finnegan managed to fortify St. Johns Bluff where Confederate troops used slave labor to construct defenses.{{cite web|title=The River War: The Timucuan Preserve in the Civil War|url=http://www.nps.gov/timu/planyourvisit/upload/civil_war_site_bulletin.pdf|website=National Park Service|publisher=U. S. Department of the Interior|accessdate=30 January 2015}} This was part of a series of Confederate defensive works that had been constructed near [[Fort Caroline]] and [[Yellow Bluff Fort Historic State Park|Yellow Bluff Fort]]. On September 11 Confederates opened fire on Union gunboat USS Uncas approaching the bluff. The USS Patroon joined the USS Uncas and opened fire on the bluff but failed to destroy the Confederate position. The Union dispatched over 800 soldiers to Florida from [[South Carolina]] to take the bluff expecting it to be a challenging obstacle. Union reinforcements arrived on October 1 at Mayport Mills. The next day, Union soldiers under Brigadier General J.M. Brannon approached the bluff from the rear. Confederate Colonel Charles F. Hopkins was in a panic due to the Union reinforcements approaching from the rear and the Union gunboats still firing on the bluff. Captain Winston Stephens believed the Confederate position could hold off the Federal assault. However, Hopkins decided to order a retreat from the Confederate position on October 2–3. Federals occupied the Confederate position and seized the cannons. Two days later on October 5 the Federals moved on to nearby Yellow Bluff Fort which had also retreated.{{cite web|title=Defender of the St. Johns River|url=http://www.exploresouthernhistory.com/yellowblufffort.html|publisher=Explore Southern History|accessdate=14 May 2016}} File:FineganJoseph63.jpg|
Brigadier General Joseph Finnegan File:CSAWinstonStephns.jpg|
Confederate Captain Winston Stephens File:John M Brannan.jpg|
Brigadier General John M. Brannan ==Aftermath== Jacksonville was reoccupied on October 3 after the Union victory at St. Johns Bluff. Finnegan believed that Hopkins' retreat from St. Johns Bluff was a "gross military blunder" but Hopkins still defended his position for retreating. The Confederate threat in North Florida no longer prevented Federals from seizing the St. Johns River and Jacksonville.{{cite web|title=The Battle of St. Johns Bluff - Jacksonville, Florida|url=http://www.exploresouthernhistory.com/stjohnsbattle.html|publisher=Explore Southern History|accessdate=14 May 2016}}{{cite web|title=Tag Archives: St. Johns Bluff|url=http://www.floridamemory.com/blog/tag/st-johns-bluff/|publisher=Florida Memory|accessdate=14 May 2016}} ==See also== *[[Florida in the American Civil War]] ==References== {{reflist|refs= [http://www.nps.gov/hps/abpp/battles/fl003.htm National Park Service Battle Summary]}} *[http://www.nps.gov/hps/abpp/battles/fl003.htm National Park Service battle description] *[http://www.nps.gov/hps/abpp/CWSII/CWSACReportFloridaUpdate.pdf CWSAC Report Update] ==External links== *[http://www.nps.gov/foca/ Fort Caroline National Memorial] - official National Park Service website {{Florida in the Civil War}} [[Category:Battles of the Lower Seaboard Theater and Gulf Approach of the American Civil War|Saint John's Bluff]] [[Category:History of Jacksonville, Florida]] [[Category:Union victories of the American Civil War|Saint John's Bluff]] [[Category:Battles of the American Civil War in Florida|Saint John's]] [[Category:Duval County, Florida]] [[Category:Conflicts in 1862|St. Johns Bluff]] [[Category:1862 in Florida]]
